_prev_prog_3.Description: The Lima Water Treatment Plant (WTP) maintains a high level of operator and maintenance training.  Employees perform periodic reviews and participate as a group in updating and implementing new operating procedures, process equipment changes and employee operational training. Written standard operating procedures are reviewed at least annually, but more often as work is being performed, and updated as needed.  The performance of annual process hazard analysis reviews, annual reviews of emergency procedures with local agencies, PPE and supply updates within the respirator program to ensure coordination with the local fire department, replacement and updates of current container leak kits, and continual reviews of emergency alarm systems are also done through group participation.  The WTP also continues its audit inspection program, as well as annual refresher training for all safety related operations and processes.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
General Information

The Lima Water Treatment Plant (WTP) is a municipally owned and operated water purification facility that uses chlorine for water disinfection.  The existing chlorination system utilizes gaseous chlorine and consists of eight (8) 1 ton cylinder containers, four (4) digital scales, vacuum regulators on each cylinder, an automatic changeover valve, three (3) 500 lbs./day and two (2) 1000 lbs./day chlorinators, and a distribution manifold.  The average chlorine usage is 560 lbs./day.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Training and chemical awareness are key factors in the department's Emergency Response Plan (ERP).  All operators receive annual refresher training on best safe work practices with regard to chlorine use and feed processes.  Training is performed every three (3) years, per the RMP requirements.  Knowledge and comprehension of chlorine handling practices, storage, usage, and spill prevention are reviewed annually in house.  The last chlorine safety training was 9/12/18.  Chlorine containment and feed operations are secure within the facility and only accessible to authorized plant personnel.  The ERP was last reviewed on 5/11/21 with the operations and management groups.



Worst Case Scenario

Chlorine is received and unloaded in one (1) ton cylinders.  The chemical unloading procedures are carefully designed and reviewed annually.  Due to the fact that a release can occur during the unloading process, no passive mitigation is used.  In the event of a full cylinder release, the endpoint distance is approximately 1.3 miles within a 10 minute time span.



Alternate Release Scenario

In the event of a leak from a one (1) ton cylinder already put in service, housed within the chlorination room of the administrative building, passive mitigation is applicable.  The endpoint distance is approximately .1 miles, with release duration of approximately 60 minutes.



Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemi

cal Specific Prevention Steps

Lima WTP is in compliance with OSHA regulations with respect to the Accidental Release Prevention Program.  The chemical specific prevention steps are compliant with all Ohio EPA requirements, Recommended Standards for Water Works, 1997 - Ten States Standards, Chlorine Institute Standards, and Regulations concerning Chlorination Equipment and Facilities for Public Water Supplies.



Five year Accident History

The Lima WTP has had no accidental releases of chlorine in the past 5 years.  There have been no accidental chlorine releases in the known history of the plant that have resulted in injury to off-site personnel or public evacuations.



Emergency Response Program

A written copy of the ERP is located at the WTP, as well as in the administrative offices at City Hall.  The plan includes first aid procedures, medical management of chlorine exposure information, emergency response training, pre-emergency coordination guidelines, a summary of emergency chlorine release procedures, and a quick reference guide allowing an operator to respond immediately and accurately in the event of an observed or detected chlorine release.  The Allen County Local Emergency Planning Committee is the overall coordinator of emergency response services, although the WTP is diligent in contacting the Lima Fire Department as part of their current program.  Lima Fire Department performs a periodic walk-through of the WTP and jointly reviews training requirements for both parties, equipment and personal protective equipment (PPE) uniformity, and annual refresher guidelines.  The next walk-through is scheduled for the fall of 2021.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Lima WTP is committed to reviewing and following the guidelines presented in the ERP.  All training and management programs will be reviewed annually and updated as necessary.  The City will support the implementation of these programs as a part of the Risk Management Program.  With each tra
ining opportunity, procedural reviews are performed to ensure continued best safe work practices.
